instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Wi-Fi problems
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which has suffered liquid but still turns on and working fine apart from the Wi-Fi greyed out. The damage was near to the WiFi chip. I replaced UL001 & CL071 as they were both corroded. Also noticed that the TP for <SIGNAL>WLBT_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> was damaged so i've ran a trace from JL103 to the TP. this now reads the correct diode reading but it only gives me 0.4v. 

On further investigation the signal to turn this on comes from <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> so i presume that is faulty. 

My question is can the <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> be replaced? I would have to try and find a brand new one as i don't have a stencil.

Not sure what the enable voltage should be and if anyone knows this would help, I could inject the voltage to see if the Wi-FI starts to work before tackling the <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Wi-Fi problems
threads.message:
Yes, you can change <CHIP>U8100</CHIP>.
The PMUs can be changed between 14" and 16" M1 models.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Wi-Fi problems
